channel.title: Portforwarding Issue.. HELP
channel.description: I have just recently switched internet.. I used to be portforwarded.. I have my wireless router portforwarded for 43594 I believe.. However when I go to "Canyouseeme.org" it states "It can not see it on port (43594).".. What could the problem maybe be? I have switched from Verizon DSL (junk internet) to Comcast Cable Internet. Is there anything different that I'd have to do because I switched internet? Please help, thanks!

item.title: Portforwarding Issue.. HELP
item.dc:creator: @skiller8860 skiller8860
item.description:
@skiller8860 wrote:

So for example the run > cmd > ipconfig static thing would be i.e. 192.168.x.xxx right?

Read full topic

item.title: Portforwarding Issue.. HELP
item.dc:creator: @Damoiscool Damoiscool
item.description:
@Damoiscool wrote:

If you are connecting to the server on your dads computer (or wherever the server is running) you will need to use 127.0.0.1, if you are using your school laptop (or another computer) that is on the same network you need to use the static ip of the computer that the server is running on
(Run > CMD > ipconfig). If you are connecting outside your local network you use the no-ip

Read full topic

@skiller8860 wrote:

Okay, I’ll get back to ya on how it works. Thanks! ^_^.

@ultimatepkvillage wrote:

use 127.0.0.1 to login while others use no-ip

Read full topic

item.title: Portforwarding Issue.. HELP
item.dc:creator: @skiller8860 skiller8860
item.description:
@skiller8860 wrote:

Nope, figured out how to hide it on my dads computer xD. Here’s what I did… I made it so when his PC starts up, No-ip and a javascript starts up. Here is what is in the javascript…

var WindowStyle_Hidden = 0 var objShell = WScript.CreateObject("WScript.Shell") var result = objShell.Run("cmd.exe /c run.bat", WindowStyle_Hidden)

Which opens the run.bat in the file that it’s in. Also, it makes it hidden :D. It just makes it run as cmd.exe in the background. Only way to put the server down is by either logging off, or when you press ctrl + alt + delete and stop the process “cmd.exe” :P. Took me a while to find this code, but it works and shall I say, I’m quite proud of it xD. So now my server works, only problem is… I don’t know what IP to use to connect to the server which is hosted on the same internet. Do I use my IP? Do I use my no-ip? Do I use 127.0.0.1? Do I use 10.0.0.1? What? Thanks for the help.

Read full topic

item.title: Portforwarding Issue.. HELP
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

ultimatepkvillage:

Have you tried http://portforward.com/english/routers/port_forwarding/routerindex.htm and seen if your router model was on there to portforward for a rsps if so then I’m guessing your provider does not allow port 43594 to be opened.

He’s also on a school laptop that has a lot of features admin-blocked. We talked on skype about it.
@OP Like I said, unless you can get past the firewall on your laptop, I don’t see you getting this to work. Or you can host on your dads computer but there isn’t really anyway to hide it.
Also, you can try installing uTorrent on the laptop, if that works it can make an exception in the firewall and you can change it’s port to 43594.

Read full topic

item.title: Portforwarding Issue.. HELP
item.dc:creator: @Naseem Naseem
item.description:
@Naseem wrote:

Try to follow my steps maybe you forgot one by mistake:

1- Open up your CMD then type ipconfig, then save the IPv4 Address
1- Make a port in your router, 43594 and paste the IPv4 adress on your port
2- make no-ip
3- change your client ip to your no-ip (after that complier)
4- Run your client
5- Go to http://www.yougetsignal.com/tools/open-ports/
and check your port after running your source/client.

Read full topic
